item.title:
When a frog is bloated it is due to a pathologic condition where fluid that circulates in the lymphatic system builds up outside of its normal area.
This is Shuttles, a 9 yo female albino African claw frog who was rescued

item.title:
2/3) Since then, we've been wondering:
A: Is there any way to experimentally test for the synaptic distance function used by the brain?
B: Would the brain really use a Euclidean distance function in synaptic weight space, or is there a more plausible alternative?
item.description:
2/3) Since then, we've been wondering:
A: Is there any way to experimentally test for the synaptic distance function used by the brain?
B: Would the brain really use a Euclidean distance function in synaptic weight space, or is there a more plausible alternative?
item.content:encoded: 2/3) Since then, we've been wondering: A: Is there any way to experimentally test for the synaptic distance function used by the brain? B: Would the brain really use a Euclidean distance function in synaptic weight space, or is there a more plausible alternative?

item.title:
3/3) @rmnpogodin delivers a wonderful set of proofs and experiments here to answer question A.
tl;dr: He shows that you can use the distribution of synaptic weights to test between different potential synaptic distance functions.
Stay tuned for an answer to question B... ğŸ™‚
